qas.question: Does minority leader act solely to advance party objectives?

answers.text: in consultation with other party colleagues

qas.question: Does minority leader always employ same strategy for party objectives?

answers.text: options selected depend on a wide range of circumstances

qas.question: Does dissension and cohesion of majority party factor into minority strategy?

answers.text: may provide the minority leader with greater opportunities to achieve his or her priorities than if the majority party exhibited high degrees of party cohesion

qas.question: What did majority parties use to advance bills in the 1900's?
What is usually strongly holding the Progressives together?
In what year did Democrats have a majority?

plausible_answers.text: greater opportunities to achieve his or her priorities

qas.question: What did Progressives cohesion in 1900 provide for the majority party?
What works better for a majority leader than Republicans being in disarray?

context: Devise Minority Party Strategies. The minority leader, <a0_0>in consultation with other party colleagues<a0_0/>, has <b3_0>a range of strategic options<b3_0/> that he or she can employ to advance minority party objectives. The <a1_0>options selected depend on a wide range of circumstances<a1_0/>, such as the visibility or significance of the issue and the degree of <b4_0>cohesion<b4_0/> within the majority party. For instance, a majority party riven by internal dissension, as occurred during the early <b5_0>1900s<b5_0/> when Progressive and "regular" Republicans were at loggerheads, <a2_0>may provide the minority leader with <b6_0>greater opportunities to achieve his or her priorities<b6_0/> than if the majority party exhibited <b7_0>high degrees of party cohesion<b7_0/><a2_0/>. Among the variable strategies available to the minority party, which can vary from bill to bill and be used in combination or at different stages of the lawmaking process, are the following:
